thread.title: Will Procter & Gamble Beat Revenue Estimates in 1Q16?
thread.title_full: Will Procter & Gamble Beat Revenue Estimates in 1Q16? - Yahoo Finance

author: Penny Morgan
title: Will Procter & Gamble Beat Revenue Estimates in 1Q16?
text:
1Q16 Earnings: What Can You Expect from Procter & Gamble? 
Last quarter overview Procter & Gamble (PG), or P&G, is set to release its 1Q16 earnings before the markets open on October 23, 2015. The first quarter for fiscal 2016 ended on September 30. P&G’s earnings were ahead of Wall Street analysts’ consensus expectations in 4Q15. The quarter ended June 30, 2015. However, revenue just missed the analysts’ estimates for 4Q15.
Procter & Gamble’s net revenue fell by 9% to $17.8 billion in 4Q15, compared to $19.6 billion in 4Q14. The reported revenue was negatively impacted by foreign exchange and saw a 9% fall. The volume saw a 3% fall. This was offset by a 3% average increase in the prices of products across the globe.

Wall Street analysts’ expectations For 1Q16 ending on September 30, 2015, Wall Street analysts’ consensus revenue estimate is $17.5 billion. This is a 15.9% fall from the revenue in the same quarter last year.
P&G’s organic sales for 4Q15 didn’t change. However, both Colgate-Palmolive (CL) and Kimberly-Clark’s (KMB) 2Q15 organic sales grew ~4% each. For fiscal 2015, P&G’s organic sales grew for all five segments except for the Beauty, Hair, and Personal Care segment. Overall, the organic sales grew by 1% for fiscal 2015.
Will reshaping increase the revenue? P&G aims to reshape the company and refocus on ten product categories and 65 brands. This could be the best way to leverage its core competencies. It would result in leading global positions. It would also impact P&G’s top line. As a result, P&G divested its beauty brands in a merger with Coty (COTY). To learn more about the deal, please read Coty Buys 43 Procter & Gamble Brands: What Investors Should Know .
About the company Procter & Gamble is one of the leading consumer staples, or XLP, firms. The company manufactures and sells household products around the world. It operates through five segments. Some of its major brands include Olay, Pantene, Head & Shoulders, Gillette, and Pampers. To learn more about the company, please read Procter & Gamble: Your Guide to the Largest Consumer Staples Firm .
P&G has exposure in the iShares S&P 500 Growth ETF (IVW). It accounts for 1.1% of the portfolio’s total weight.
